location: Java, Indonesia (Mataram Sultanate and surrounding regions)

causes: Internal struggles within the Mataram Sultanate over royal succession.
Rising Dutch East India Company (VOC) influence in Javanese politics.
Regional rulers seeking autonomy from central Javanese control.
events_leading_up_to_war: The death of Sultan Amangkurat II in 1703 led to a contested succession.
The Dutch supported Amangkurat III initially but later backed his rival Pakubuwono I.

result.general: Dutch-backed factions gained control over Java, solidifying VOC dominance.

treaties.name: Treaty of Giyanti
terms: Java was divided between the Sultanate of Yogyakarta and the Surakarta Sunanate.
The Dutch East India Company (VOC) became the ultimate power broker in Java.

territorial_changes: Mataram Sultanate was weakened and divided into separate principalities.
Dutch VOC solidified its influence over Javanese rulers.

allies: Islamic clerical groups opposed to Dutch influence

Mataram_Sultanate: Raden Mas Said (Prince Sambernyawa, guerrilla leader)

Mataram_Sultanate.tactics: Guerrilla warfare, city sieges, and regional alliances

Dutch_East_India_Company_VOC.navy: Superior maritime forces with VOC warships
Dutch_East_India_Company_VOC.tactics: European-style warfare, fortification strategies, and divide-and-rule policies

Mataram_Sultanate.dead_and_wounded: Tens of thousands, including widespread civilian casualties
Mataram_Sultanate.destruction: Multiple Javanese cities and palaces were destroyed

Dutch_East_India_Company_VOC.dead_and_wounded: Several thousand, mostly in prolonged guerrilla battles
Dutch_East_India_Company_VOC.destruction: Fortified settlements occasionally attacked by rebels

major_battles.name: Battle of Kartasura
major_battles.description: Raden Mas Said and his anti-Dutch forces captured the Kartasura palace, forcing Pakubuwono II to flee.
major_battles.outcome: Temporary rebel victory, but Dutch reinforcements later retook the city.

major_battles.name: Siege of Surakarta
major_battles.description: Final stronghold of rebel resistance before the Treaty of Giyanti was signed.
major_battles.outcome: Dutch-backed forces secured victory, leading to the partition of Java.

texts.name: Babad Tanah Jawi
texts.author: Various Javanese court scribes
texts.details: Records Javanese history, including the war from different perspectives.

texts.name: VOC Colonial Records
texts.author: Dutch East India Company officials
texts.details: Details VOC military campaigns and alliances in Java.

archaeological_evidence.description: Remnants of the destroyed royal court during the war.
Colonial-era fortresses in Batavia (Jakarta) and Semarang.

political: Java was divided between Yogyakarta and Surakarta.
Dutch influence over Javanese politics became entrenched.
long_term_effects: Set the stage for full Dutch colonial control over Indonesia in the 19th century.
Weakened indigenous resistance against European rule.

military: Showcased early guerrilla warfare tactics used against colonial forces.
Demonstrated the effectiveness of European-style fortifications in Java.
political: Shifted power away from Javanese sultans toward Dutch-controlled administrations.
Led to the eventual fall of indigenous rule and complete Dutch colonial control by the 1800s.
cultural: Inspired Javanese folklore about resistance and heroism.
Created lasting divisions within Javanese aristocracy, influencing modern politics in Indonesia.
